Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou 213164 PR China dSchool of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou 213164, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors: ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors: High N2O selectivity of MnOx-TiO2 catalyst hinders its development in ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) of NOx. Herein, a series of MnOx-TiO2 catalyst with different Mn/Ti ratio were prepared by wet-impregnation method to study the N2O formation during ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) of NOx from the perspective of catalyst. It is found that MnOx and TiO2 species are the mainly redox and acid sites for the NH3-SCR denitration reaction over MnOx-TiO2 catalyst, respectively. As the Mn/Ti ratio increases, MnOx species layer expanded on TiO2 support, leading to increase of redox sites but decrease of surface acid sites. These changes contribute to the occurrence of the no-selective oxidation of NH3 on MnOx species and the over-activation of NH3 at Mn-Ti interface, resulting in the formation of N2O via the route of 2NH3 + 2O2 → N2O + 3H2O and 4NO + 4NH3 + 3O2 → 4N2O + 6H2O, respectively. Through this work, it can be speculated that both improving MnOx dispersion and increasing surface acidity of catalyst are feasible strategy for suppressing the N2O formation on MnOx-TiO2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N2O MnOx/TiO2 Mn/Ti ratio NH3-SCR 1 Introduction Flue gas of fossil fuels combustion contains a large amount of nitrogen oxides (NOₓ), which can lead to a series of environmental issues (such as acid rains, photochemical smog and ozone depletion) and threaten human health [1]. Selective catalytic reduction using NH3 as reducing agent (NH3-SCR) is one of the most used technologies in removing NOₓ [2–4]. Catalyst is the core of NH3-SCR technology, which determines the operation temperature of NH3-SCR denitration system. Nowadays, V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts have been used to the NH3-SCR denitration for large coal-fired boilers because the fuel gas of large coal-fired boilers could provide the required activity temperature window (320–400°C) [5–7]. The temperature of fuel gas from industrial boiler and small-medium coal-fired boiler is always below 200°C. To ensure the high denitration efficiency of V2O5-TiO2 based NH3-SCR system for low temperature flue gas, the method of increasing V2O5 loading content and adding preheater has been adopted [6, 7]. However, increasing V2O5 loading content might increase the risk of second pollution resulted from the slip of high toxicity of V2O5, while preheater cause a high energy consumption. The development of novel catalysts is preferred method for flue gas NOx purification at low temperature. Among the studied transition metal and rare earth metal oxides catalysts, costly and environment friendly MnOx based catalyst is the most proposed low temperature NH3-SCR catalyst owing to their excellent low temperature activity [1–9]. However, in order to promote the industrial application of MnOx-based NH3-SCR catalysts, it is necessary to improve the resistance to SO2 poisoning and decrease the high N2O selectivity. In-depth understanding in the mechanism of SO2 poisoning and N2O formation is beneficial to the design of highly efficient MnOx-based catalyst. It is widely approved that the formation of ammonium sulfate salt and/or manganese sulfate salt deactivates MnOx-based catalysts in the presence of SO2 [10, 11]. However, the N2O formation mechanism over MnOx-based NH3-SCR catalysts is controversial. N2O mainly comes from side reaction of the non-selective catalytic reduction (NSCR: 4NO+3O2+4NH3→4N2O+6H2O) and non-selective oxidation of NH3 (2NH3+2O2→N2O+3H2O) during NH3-SCR of NO [12–14]. Revealing the relationship between catalyst structure and N2O formation can be facilitated to the design of MnOx based catalyst. Tang et al. investigated the origination of N2O from NH3-SCR of NO over β-MnO2 and α-Mn2O3 via combining transient reactions of NH3 and various characterization measurements and pointed out that β-MnO2 shows higher NO formation rate than α-Mn2O3 due to its high amounts of active oxygen species that lead to over-activation of NH3 [15]. Yang et al. studied the N2O formation pathways via in-situ IR and found that decomposition of NHNO contributes the N2O formation on MnO2 Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, but the decomposition of NH4NO3 is also a N2O formation route over Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 [16]. Supported MnOx based catalyst always shows a higher activity, less N2O formation and better resistance to H2O and SO2 in comparison with pure MnOx catalysts [17, 18]. In our recent work [19], the effect of supports on N2O formation over MnOx/MOx (M=Si, Al and Ti) was studied, and found that MnOx/TiO2 catalysts shows the lowest N2O formation amount due to the synergistic effect between TiO2 support and MnOx that can separate NH3 and NO+O2 activation sites. Nevertheless, there is still a lot of N2O formation on the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. According to the results of isotopic labeling and in situ FT-IR, Ettireddy et al. suggested that N2O come from the reaction between NH3 and surface oxygen on MnOx species rather than adsorbed nitric oxide [20]. The effect of gaseous NO concentration and N2O selectivity on MnOx/TiO2 was investigated by Yang [13] et al., and it is proposed that N2O is mainly generated via NSCR route. Wang et al. studied the source of N and O in N2O formation during NH3-SCR reaction over MnOx/TiO2 and pointed out that N source comes from both NH3 and NO, while O source comes from the gaseous O2 [21]. Although so much work as above has been done, there still lack a deep insight of N2O formation from the perspective of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. In this work, a series of MnOx/TiO2 catalysts with different Mn/Ti ratio was prepared by wet impregnation method. The samples were characterized by XRD, BET, HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. The aim of this study was to demonstrate the effect of dispersed MnOx species on the formation of N2O over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst, and then provide some suggestion on designing highly efficient MnOx based SCR catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were used without pretreatment. Traditional wet impregnation method was used to fabricate MnOx supported on TiO2 catalysts. Generally, a certain of 50wt% Mn(NO3)2 solution (Aladdin, AR, 50wt% in H2O) and 2 g TiO2 (Aladdin, 99.8% metal basis, anatase, 2–25 nm, hydrophilic) were mixed in 40 mL deionized water. Then, the mixed solution was heated under vigorous stirring until the water was evaporated. The obtained solid was dried at 120 °C and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. Finally, MnOx/TiO2 (MnyTi, y means the Mn/Ti atomic ratio, y = 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.5) catalysts were obtained. For comparison study, MnOx catalyst was prepared by calcining Mn(NO3)2 at 400 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Characterization and catalytic activity test The detail of characterization and catalytic activity test are presented in supplementary information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity Fig. 1 shows the catalytic activity test results of samples for NH3-SCR of NOx. As shown in Fig. 1a, the NH3-SCR activity of MnOx sample increases with increasing reaction temperature from 100 to 150 °C, and it reaches the highest NOx removal efficiency of 81% at 150 °C. For MnTi samples, their activity increases firstly and then decrease as increasing the reaction temperature, and all MnTi samples reach the highest NOx removal efficiency at 180 °C. The Mn/Ti ratio has a significant influence on the catalytic activity of MnTi catalysts. Mn0.2Ti catalyst shows the best activity at the reaction temperature below 180 °C. When the reaction temperature is higher than 180 °C, the NOx conversion of MnTi catalysts decreases with the increase of Mn/Ti ratio. Fig. 1b presents the N2O concentration in the outlet gas of the NH3-SCR activity test at different reaction temperature. For MnOx catalyst, the formed N2O increases from 54 ppm to 183 ppm as the reaction temperature increases from 100 °C to 210 °C, and its concentration is always larger than 159 ppm at the temperature range of 210–300 °C. These results suggest that MnOx catalyst produces a large amount of N2O during NH3-SCR of NOx reaction. MnTi catalysts show much lower N2O formation than MnOx catalyst. However, the amount of N2O produced on MnTi cannot be ignored, and it is closely related to the reaction temperature and Mn/Ti ratio. The N atom amount of converted NOx and NH3 and formed N2O are displayed in Fig S1. The N atom resulted from N2O is always larger than the difference between converted NH3 and NO, inferring that N2O is resulted from both non-selective catalytic reduction and NH3 oxidation reactions. Furthermore, it is observed that the difference between converted NH3 and NO on catalysts increases with the enhanced Mn/Ti ratio, indicating the ratio of N2O resulted from NH3 oxidation is increased. 3.2 Structure analysis Fig. 2 shows the XRD diffraction patterns of prepared samples. TiO2 support presents the typical diffraction patterns assigned to anatase phase (PDF#21–1272). The diffraction lines of MnOx are coincide with the pattern of pyrolusite MnO2 (PDF#01–0799). No obvious diffraction peaks of MnOx can be found in the diffraction patterns of MnTi samples, indicating that the loaded MnOx species are well dispersed on TiO2 supports or its size is smaller than the detection limit of XRD. As the Mn/Ti ratio increases, the intensity of diffraction peaks of TiO2 decreases. The linear correlation between TiO2 weight content and its diffraction peak intensity at 25.2° was analyzed. As shown in Fig S2, the square of correlation coefficient (r) is 0.89, which implies that the decreased TiO2 content might be the main reason for the decrease of diffraction peak intensity of TiO2. Table 1 lists the BET surface area and pore structure data of samples. specific surface area of TiO2 and MnOx samples is 86.5 and 13.1 m2∙g−1, respectively. The specific surface area of MnTi catalysts is smaller than that of TiO2, and their value decreases with the increase of Mn/Ti ratio, which might be resulted from either the reduction of TiO2 content and/or the sintering of catalyst. The HRTEM images presenting TiO2 (101) plane of MnTi catalysts were selected for investigating the MnOx species on TiO2 support. Fig. 3 a-c shows the HRTEM image of MnTi sample. Obviously, a thin layer of amorphous MnOx species (marked with red cycle) covers on the (101) plane of TiO2 support. The size of amorphous MnOx species expands as the increase of Mn/Ti ratio, thus the coverage area of the TiO2 support by the MnOx species is enlarged, and the lattice line of TiO2 (101) plane becomes more less observable. Based on above results, the change of MnOx species (blue) on TiO2 support (grey) accompanied with increasing Mn/Ti ratio is proposed and presented in Fig. 3d. It is generally known that the catalytic properties of MnOx based catalysts are strongly associated with the dimension and composition of active component-support interface [22–24]. For MnTi catalyst, a higher Mn/Ti ratio leads to the formation of MnOx species with larger size, and then resulting the change in the physical chemistry properties of catalyst. These changes and their impact on the NH3-SCR reaction will be discussed below. 3.2 Surface properties analysis XPS was used to analysis the surface component and valence composition of MnTi and MnOx samples. Fig. 4 a shows the Mn 2p XPS spectra of MnTi and MnOx samples. The ratio of Mn species with different valance was obtained by fitting Mn2p3/2 and listed in Table S1 [25, 26]. MnTi samples show the same Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio as MnOx samples, indicating that all samples show the same valence composition. The O1s spectra of samples are presented in Fig. 4b. The peak of O1s was divided into lattice oxygen (Oβ) and surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) [26, 27]. Notably, all samples show the same peak position of Oβ, while the peak position of Oα is shifted to higher binding energy with the increase of Mn/Ti ratio. Furthermore, the Oα content of MnTi catalyst is enhanced with increased Mn/Ti ratio. These results suggest that MnTi catalyst with a higher Mn/Ti ratio have more chemisorbed oxygen that exhibits higher reactivity. Fig. 5 shows the H2-TPR profiles of prepared samples. TiO2 presents a small H2 consumption peak at 550–700 °C due to the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ [28]. After loading with MnOx species, two peaks located below 550 °C can be observed. According to the previous studies [29, 30], these two peaks can be attributed to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ (Peak1) and Mn3+ to Mn2+ (Peak2), respectively. With the increase of Mn/Ti ratio, the peak area of Peak1 and Peak2 for MnTi catalyst increases, and their peak position moves to a higher temperature, implying that the MnOx species on MnTi catalyst with a higher Mn/Ti ratio shows a poorer oxidizing ability. It has been proved that over-activation of NH3 resulted from high oxidizing ability of Mn-based catalysts lead to the formation of N2O [15–31]. The adsorption-activation of NH3 occurs on MnOx species, the MnOx species with stronger oxidizing ability is more likely to cause the over-activation of NH3, and thus leading to the formation of higher amounts of N2O. From catalytic activity test results presented in Fig. 1, more N2O forms on MnTi catalyst with higher MnOx loading content. This abnormal phenomenon suggests that MnOx species is not NH3 adsorption sites over MnTi catalyst during NH3-SCR, but it can promote the activation of adsorbed NH3 species. NH3-TPD-MS was used to analysis the NH3 adsorption and activation ability of samples. As displayed in Fig. 6 and Fig S4, TiO2 shows a broad NH3 desorption peak at 100–600 °C. Although a broad peak is found in the NH3-TPD profile at the temperature above 350 °C, only the peak due to oxygen can be observed in MS spectra, indicating that MnOx has poor NH3 adsorption capacity. MnTi catalysts shows a smaller desorption peak than TiO2, and their peak area decreases with the increase of Mn/Ti ratio. Based on above results, it can be concluded that the acid sites for NH3 adsorption on MnTi catalysts are mainly provided by surface Ti species. MnOx species covers the acid sites on TiO2, which results in the decrease of NH3 adsorption capacity of MnTi catalysts. Notably, as the Mn/Ti ratio increases, the desorption peak of NH3 above 250 °C shifts to a lower temperature, which indicates that the loaded MnOx species is facilitate to the activation of NH3 adsorbed on TiO2. Interestingly, from the MS results in Fig S4, MnTi catalysts show a broad desorption peak due to lattice oxygen at the temperature above 400 °C when the Mn/Ti atomic ratio is larger than 0.1. According to the results of H2-TPR, the oxidizing ability of MnTi catalysts decrease with increasing Mn/Ti ratio, demonstrating that the surface lattice oxygen on the MnTi catalyst with a smaller Mn/Ti ratio is easier to desorb. However, there no desorption peak of oxygen is observed in the profiles of Mn0.05Ti and Mn0.1Ti samples. Thus, it can be inferred that the surface lattice oxygen of MnOx easily interacts with adsorbed NH3 on TiO2. For the MnTi catalyst with low Mn/Ti ratio, the amount of active lattice oxygen provided by the MnOx species is all consumed by adsorbed NH3 to form N2, N2O, NOx and H2O. The NH3 species absorbed nearby the MnOx-TiO2 interface cannot consume the lattice oxygen provided by MnOx, thus, both desorption peaks of NH3 and lattice oxygen can be observed in the profiles of MnTi (Mn/Ti ratio ≥ 0.2) catalysts. In-situ DRIFT spectra was used to further investigate the NH3 adsorption-desorption on MnTi an MnOx samples. As shown in Fig. 7 a, several peaks due to the adsorbed NH3 on Lewis (labeled as L) and Brønsted (labeled as B) acid sites can be observed in the spectra of TiO2 after NH3 purging at 50 °C [32–34]. As the temperature increases, the peak intensity decreases due to the desorption of adsorbed NH3. Notably, there remains many peaks of adsorbed NH3 species even increasing temperature to 350 °C, indicating that the NH3 species adsorbed on TiO2 is very stable. All peaks of adsorbed NH3 species emerged in the spectra of TiO2 can be found in the spectrum of Mn0.05Ti sample at 50 °C (displayed in Fig. 7b). The difference is that their peak intensity reduces more quickly with the increase of temperature, and the peaks of NH3 species adsorbed on B acid sites disappears at the temperature above 200 °C. In the spectra of MnTi samples with a higher Mn/Ti ratio, fewer peaks are found, and the peak intensity of adsorbed NH3 species decreases more quickly with increasing temperature. Notably, only the peaks due to adsorbed NH3 species on L acid sites can be seen in the spectra of Mn0.5Ti sample (Fig. 7d), and these peaks almost disappears when the temperature is increased to 300 °C. Based on above results, it can be concluded that MnOx loading reduces the amounts of acid sites on MnTi catalyst, but it can promote the activation of NH3 species. The adsorbed species over catalyst during reaction process was investigated via the in-situ DRIFT spectra of NO + O2 + NH3 co-adsorption and results are shown in Fig. 8 . With the introduction of NO + O2 + NH3, several peaks at 1750−1640, 1600, 1580, 1537, 1460, 1313 1280 and 1237 cm−1 are emerged at the spectra of Mn0.05Ti, Mn0.2Ti and Mn0.5Ti samples. The peaks at 1600 and 1237 cm−1 are attributed to the coordinated NH3 bound to the L acid sites (1600 and 1237 cm−1), and the peaks at 1750−1640 and 1460 cm−1 can be assigned to the ionic NH4 + bound to the B acid sites [31–35]. Peaks due to monodentate nitrite and bidentate nitrate is fund at 1580 cm−1 and 1280 cm−1, respectively [33–35]. The co-existence of peak of adsorbed NH3 and NOx in the spectra suggested that the NH3-SCR reaction over MnTi catalyst might occur via Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [35]. The NH2 species results from due to NH3 activation (oxidation) are the key intermediate for NH3-SCR reaction, thus two peaks of NH2 species results from are observed at 1537 and 1313 cm−1 [16]. The over-activation of NH3 species lead to the formation of NH species, which are the reaction intermediate of forming N2O [12–36]. A peak of NH species is observed at 1433 cm−1 in the spectra of Mn0.05Ti, Mn0.2Ti and Mn0.5Ti samples [37], corresponding to the results that a large amount of N2O was detected during the NH3-SCR denitration test of MnTi catalyst. 3.4 N2O formation discussion Combined with the results in this work and published studies [12–31], the NH3-SCR reaction and N2O formation route over MnTi catalyst was proposed and displayed in Fig. 8. The adsorbed NH3 was activated into -NH2 at the Mn-Ti interface on MnTi catalyst with small MnOx particles, and then react with gas NO+O2 (E-R mechanism) or adsorbed NOx (L-H mechanism) to form N2 and H2O. On the MnTi catalyst with larger MnOx particles, Mn-Ti interface can provide excess active oxygen, which leads to the over-activation of adsorbed NH3 into -NH, thereby causing the formation of N2O via reaction between -NH and gas NO+O2. Moreover, the coverage of large MnOx particles on the TiO2 suppresses the NH3 adsorption on TiO2 and causes the formation of N2O via NH3 oxidation route. On the MnTi catalyst with low Mn/Ti ratio, MnOx species can be well dispersed on TiO2 surface, thus it exists in the form of small particles. As the Mn/Ti ratio increases, MnOx species are prone to agglomerate and become larger particles, which enhance the probability of the over-activation of adsorbed NH3 and NH3 oxidation. Therefore, more N2O form on MnTi catalyst with higher Mn/Ti ratio. Fig. 9 . 4 Conclusions MnOx loading content (Mn/Ti ratio) has a significant influence on the N2O formation on MnTi catalyst. MnOx species mainly exist in the form of small particles on the MnTi catalyst with low MnOx loading content. The adsorbed NH3 can be activated into -NH2 at the Mn-Ti interface, and then react with gas NO+O2 (E-R mechanism) or adsorbed NOx (L-H mechanism) to form N2 and H2O. With the increase of MnOx loading content, MnOx species are prone to agglomerate and become larger particles on MnTi catalyst. MnTi catalyst can provide excess active oxygen at Mn-Ti interface, which leads to the over-activation of adsorbed NH3 into -NH, thereby causing the formation of N2O via reaction between -NH and gas NO+O2. Moreover, the coverage of large MnOx particles on the TiO2 suppresses the NH3 adsorption on TiO2 and causes the formation of N2O via NH3 oxidation route. coredata.dc:description: High N2O selectivity of MnOx-TiO2 catalyst hinders its development in ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) of NOx. Herein, a series of MnOx-TiO2 catalyst with different Mn/Ti ratio were prepared by wet-impregnation method to study the N2O formation during ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) of NOx from the perspective of catalyst. It is found that MnOx and TiO2 species are the mainly redox and acid sites for the NH3-SCR denitration reaction over MnOx-TiO2 catalyst, respectively. As the Mn/Ti ratio increases, MnOx species layer expanded on TiO2 support, leading to increase of redox sites but decrease of surface acid sites. These changes contribute to the occurrence of the no-selective oxidation of NH3 on MnOx species and the over-activation of NH3 at Mn-Ti interface, resulting in the formation of N2O via the route of 2NH3 + 2O2 → N2O + 3H2O and 4NO + 4NH3 + 3O2 → 4N2O + 6H2O, respectively. Through this work, it can be speculated that both improving MnOx dispersion and increasing surface acidity of catalyst are feasible strategy for suppressing the N2O formation on MnOx-TiO2.
coredata.dc:title: New insight on N2O formation over MnOx/TiO2 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3
